content: Dan Kuhlmann is an Assistant Professor of Community and Regional Planning at Iowa State University.
summary: Dan Kuhlmann is an Assistant Professor of Community and Regional Planning at Iowa State University.
title: Daniel Kuhlmann

content:
Flexibility This feature can be used for publishing content such as:
 Online courses Project or software documentation Tutorials  The courses folder may be renamed. For example, we can rename it to docs for software/project documentation or tutorials for creating an online course.
Delete tutorials To remove these pages, delete the courses folder and see below to delete the associated menu link.
Update site menu After renaming or deleting the courses folder, you may wish to update any [[main]] menu links to it by editing your menu configuration at config/_default/menus.toml.
For example, if you delete this folder, you can remove the following from your menu configuration:
[[main]] name = "Courses" url = "courses/" weight = 50  Or, if you are creating a software documentation site, you can rename the courses folder to docs and update the associated Courses menu configuration to:
[[main]] name = "Docs" url = "docs/" weight = 50  Update the docs menu If you use the docs layout, note that the name of the menu in the front matter should be in the form [menu.X] where X is the folder name. Hence, if you rename the courses/example/ folder, you should also rename the menu definitions in the front matter of files within courses/example/ from [menu.example] to [menu.<NewFolderName>].
summary: Learn how to use Academic's docs layout for publishing online courses, software documentation, and tutorials.
title: Overview

title: Example Page 2

summary: In December 2018, the Minneapolis city council approved anew comprehensive plan that, once implemented, will make Minneapolis the first major city in the country to eliminate the use of single-family zoning restrictions. In this project, I study the initial impact of this pro-posed change on the sales prices of affected properties. I estimate a seriesof difference-in-differences models comparing the price of properties with3-kilometers of the Minneapolis border in the year before and year afterthe  city  adopted  the  plan.  I  find  that  compared  to  similar  unaffectedproperties in surrounding cities, the Minneapolis plan change was associated with a 3 and 5 percentage point increase in the price of affectedproperties. Additionally, I find some evidence that this price increase isdue to the new development option it offers property owners. I find that the plan-related price increases are larger in inexpensive neighborhoods and for properties that are small relative to their immediate neighbors. While we should be cautious drawing too much significance from these initial results, they provide some evidence that there is demand for denser housing in Minneapolis.
title: Working Paper -- Upzoning and Single-Family Housing Prices: A (very) early analysis of the Minneapolis 2040Plan.

summary: Do the characteristics of our neighbour’s house affect how we view our own home? In this paper, I examine the importance of local comparisons in housing assessments by testing whether the size of one’s home relative to others in their neighbourhood influences their housing satisfaction. I use a unique feature of the 1993 American Housing Survey, in which the US Census Bureau randomly surveyed 988 housing units around the country and a cluster of approximately 10 of their nearest neighbours. I use these data to test whether a unit’s relative size in its neighbourhood influences the occupant’s housing satisfaction while controlling for a series of occupant and unit characteristics. I find evidence that relative position matters. Those living in comparatively small houses are more likely to express dissatisfaction with their home than people living in units that are large relative to other houses in their neighbourhood cluster.
title: Coveting your neighbour’s house: understanding the positional nature of residential satisfaction

summary: Does the presence of blighted housing affect nearby property owner’s decision to maintain their units? Does demolishing these distressed houses increase maintenance investment? In this paper, I examine these questions by testing whether exposure to targeted demolitions of abandoned and distressed housing affects changes in the external condition of nearby houses. Using data from two waves of a property survey in Cleveland, OH, my models suggest that, compared to a control group of houses exposed to vacant housing, proximity to demolitions decrease the likelihood that a property’s condition deteriorated between 2015 and 2018 and increase the likelihood that it improved.
title: Working Paper -- Building up After Tearing Down: The Impact of Demolitions on Residential Investment

summary: We examine the fiscal consequences of sustained population loss in American cities. We find the starkest difference between growing and declining cities in their levels of social and economic distress: Declining cities have higher rates of poverty and crime. Our evidence also suggests that shrinking cities have less fiscal capacity than growing cities, although this relationship is complicated by an apparent nonlinearity: Shrinking and rapidly growing cities both have less fiscal capacity than high-demand cities that grow slowly. Lastly, both high distress and low fiscal capacity appear to predict further population loss. Together, our evidence suggests that population loss may both increase social problems and decrease the resources available to solve them, and that declining cities may enter vicious cycles that perpetuate further decline.
title: The Social and Fiscal Consequences of Urban Decline: Evidence from Large American Cities, 1980–2010

summary: An example of linking directly to an external project website using `external_link`.
title: External Project

summary: An example of using the in-built project page.
title: Internal Project

content:
This is a simple example of how I created summary graphs of demolition activity in Cleveland.
First, prepare the data.
marker <- read.csv("//iastate.edu/lss/research/dok-lab/Cleveland Land Bank/data/r/Cleveland/data/raw data/2018-cleveland-re-survey.csv") %>% mutate(pid = as.character(Parcel.ID), marker = as.factor("Yes")) %>% select(pid, marker)cleveland.lb <- read.csv("//iastate.edu/lss/research/dok-lab/Cleveland Land Bank/data/r/Cleveland/data/raw data/cleveland lb/city demos.csv") %>% bind_rows(read.csv("//iastate.edu/lss/research/dok-lab/Cleveland Land Bank/data/r/Cleveland/data/raw data/cleveland lb/land bank demos.csv")) %>% mutate(pid = gsub("-", "", Parcel.Number)) %>% left_join(marker, by = "pid") %>% mutate(cclb.demo = ymd(Cuyahoga.Land.Bank.Demo.Date), cclb.demo.year = year(cclb.demo),city.demo = ymd(City.Demo.Date), city.demo.year = year(city.demo), demo.year = if_else(!is.na(cclb.demo.year), cclb.demo.year,if_else(!is.na(city.demo.year), city.demo.year, NA_real_)),demo.by = as.factor(if_else(!is.na(cclb.demo.year), "County Land Bank",if_else(!is.na(city.demo.year), "City", NA_character_))))graph <- cleveland.lb %>% filter(!is.na(demo.year), !is.na(marker), demo.year > 2001) %>% group_by(demo.year, demo.by) %>% summarise( n = n()) %>% mutate(series = "all") %>% select(demo.year, demo.by, series, n) %>% bind_rows((cleveland.lb %>% filter(!is.na(demo.year), is.na(marker)) %>% group_by(demo.year, demo.by) %>% summarise( n = n()) %>% mutate(series = "east")) %>% select(demo.year, series, demo.by, n)) %>% mutate(demos.location = str_c(series, ", ", demo.by)) %>% group_by(series, demo.by) %>% mutate(total_demos = cumsum(n))all.graph <- graph %>%filter(series == "all")east.graph <- graph %>%filter(series == "east")all.annual <- all.graph %>% ggplot(aes(x = demo.year, y = n, group = demo.by, linetype = demo.by)) +geom_line() +labs(x = "Year", y = "Annual Demos", linetype = "") +scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(2004, 2018, by = 2)) + scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 900), breaks = seq(0, 900, by = 100)) + theme_bw() +theme(legend.position = '', text = element_text(family = "serif")) all.cumulative <- all.graph %>% ggplot(aes(x = demo.year, y = total_demos, group = demo.by, linetype = demo.by)) +geom_line() +labs(x = "", y = "Cumulative Demos \n(Since 2004)", linetype = "", title = "All Cleveland Neighborhoods") +scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(2004, 2018, by = 2)) + scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 5000), breaks = seq(0, 5000, by = 500)) + geom_text(aes(x = 2010, y = 3500, label = "City", family = "serif")) +geom_text(aes(x = 2016.5, y = 1500, label = "Land Bank", family = "serif")) +theme_bw() +theme(legend.position = '', text = element_text(family = "serif")) east.annual <- east.graph %>% ggplot(aes(x = demo.year, y = n, group = demo.by, linetype = demo.by)) +geom_line() +labs(x = "Year", y = "", linetype = "") +scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(2004, 2018, by = 2)) + scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 900), breaks = seq(0, 900, by = 100)) + theme_bw() +theme(legend.position = "", text = element_text(family = "serif"))east.cumulative <- east.graph %>% ggplot(aes(x = demo.year, y = total_demos, group = demo.by, linetype = demo.by)) +geom_line() +labs(x = "", y = "", linetype = "", title = "Resurveyed Neighborhoods") +scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(2004, 2018, by = 2)) +scale_y_continuous(limits = c(0, 5000), breaks = seq(0, 5000, by = 500)) + theme_bw() +theme(legend.position = '', text = element_text(family = "serif"))# jpeg(file="plots/demo activity.jpeg", width = 11, height = 8.5, units = 'in', res = 850)cowplot::plot_grid(all.cumulative, east.cumulative, all.annual, east.annual, nrow = 2, ncol = 2,rel_heights = c(.6, .4), align = "v")# dev.off()To create the cumulative chart, I had to use the mutate, cumsum command.
by.hood <- cleveland.lb %>% mutate(hood = Neighborhood..imp..2012.) %>%filter(!is.na(demo.year), demo.year > 2001, (hood == "Glenville" |hood == "Broadway-Slavic Village" |hood == "Union-Miles" |hood == "Mount Pleasant" |hood == "Hough" |hood == "Kinsman" |hood == "St.Clair-Superior" |hood == "Fairfax" |hood == "Collinwood-Nottingham" |hood == "Buckeye-Shaker Square" |hood == "Buckeye-Woodhill" |hood == "Stockyards" |hood == "Clark-Fulton")) %>% group_by(demo.year, hood) %>% summarise(n = n()) %>% select(demo.year, hood, n) %>% group_by(hood) %>% mutate(total = cumsum(n))Now I can start creating the charts.
This creates the cumulative demolitions by neighbrohoods gifs.
by.hood %>% ggplot(aes(demo.year, total, group = hood)) + geom_line() + geom_segment(aes(xend = 2019, yend = total), linetype = 2, colour = 'grey') + geom_point(size = 2) + geom_text(aes(x = 2019, label = hood), hjust = 0) + transition_reveal(demo.year) + coord_cartesian(clip = 'off') + labs(title = "Total Number of Demolitions in Select \nCleveland Neighborhoods: 2004-2018",y = "Total Demolitions",x = "Year") + scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(2004, 2018, by = 2)) +scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 2400, by = 200)) +theme_minimal() +theme(plot.margin = margin(5.5, 120, 5.5, 5.5), legend.position = "none")# anim_save("gifs/cumulative demos by hood.gif")This version is the same as above, but uses demolitions per year as opposed to total, cumulative demos.
by.hood %>% ggplot(aes(demo.year, n, group = hood)) + geom_line() + geom_segment(aes(xend = 2019, yend = n), linetype = 2, colour = 'grey') + geom_point(size = 2) + geom_text(aes(x = 2019, label = hood), hjust = 0) + transition_reveal(demo.year) + coord_cartesian(clip = 'off') + labs(title = "Demolition Activity in Select \nCleveland Neighborhoods: 2004-2018",y = "Number of Demolitions",x = "Year") + scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(2004, 2018, by = 2)) +scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 400, by = 25)) +theme_minimal() +theme(plot.margin = margin(5.5, 120, 5.5, 5.5), legend.position = "none")This creates an animated version of the demolition activity per year in all of Cleveland.
all.graph %>% ggplot(aes(demo.year, n, group = demos.location, linetype = demos.location)) + geom_line() + geom_segment(aes(xend = 2019, yend = n), linetype = 3, colour = 'grey') + geom_point(size = 2) + geom_text(aes(x = 2019, label = demo.by), hjust = 0) + transition_reveal(demo.year) + coord_cartesian(clip = 'off') + labs(title = "Demolition Activity in Cleveland, OH: 2004-2018",y = "Number of Demolitions",x = "Year") + scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(2004, 2018, by = 2)) +scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 950, by = 50)) +theme_minimal() +theme(plot.margin = margin(5.5, 80, 5.5, 5.5), legend.position = "none")# anim_save("gifs/all demos.gif")And this one creates the animated graph for just the eastside.
east.graph %>% ggplot(aes(demo.year, n, group = demos.location, linetype = demos.location)) + geom_line() + geom_segment(aes(xend = 2019, yend = n), linetype = 2, colour = 'grey') + geom_point(size = 2) + geom_text(aes(x = 2019, label = demo.by), hjust = 0) + transition_reveal(demo.year) + coord_cartesian(clip = 'off') + labs(title = "Demolition Activity in Select \nEastside Cleveland Neighborhoods: 2004-2018",y = "Number of Demolitions",x = "Year") + scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(2004, 2018, by = 2)) +scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(0, 500, by = 50)) +theme_minimal() +theme(plot.margin = margin(5.5, 80, 5.5, 5.5), legend.position = "none")# anim_save("gifs/east demos.gif")
summary:
This is a simple example of how I created summary graphs of demolition activity in Cleveland.
First, prepare the data.
marker <- read.csv("//iastate.edu/lss/research/dok-lab/Cleveland Land Bank/data/r/Cleveland/data/raw data/2018-cleveland-re-survey.csv") %>% mutate(pid = as.character(Parcel.ID), marker = as.factor("Yes")) %>% select(pid, marker)cleveland.lb <- read.csv("//iastate.edu/lss/research/dok-lab/Cleveland Land Bank/data/r/Cleveland/data/raw data/cleveland lb/city demos.csv") %>% bind_rows(read.csv("//iastate.edu/lss/research/dok-lab/Cleveland Land Bank/data/r/Cleveland/data/raw data/cleveland lb/land bank demos.csv")) %>% mutate(pid = gsub("-", "", Parcel.Number)) %>% left_join(marker, by = "pid") %>% mutate(cclb.demo = ymd(Cuyahoga.Land.Bank.Demo.Date), cclb.demo.year = year(cclb.
title: Land Bank Activity Charts
